Yes, it is crucial that the developers remember the gravity of the tragedy and prioritize the memory of the victims of the September 11 attacks above the desire for profits. The World Trade Center site is a place of deep significance, representing both the loss and the resilience of the American people.

The rebuilding of the site after the attacks has been a delicate process that required a strong commitment to honoring the victims while also creating a vital, dynamic urban district. Maintaining a balance between commemoration and economic development is essential, and developers should work collaboratively with local authorities and the families of the victims to ensure that the memory of September 11 remains central to the redevelopment plan.

Moreover, it is important to remember that the redevelopment of the World Trade Center district represents a commitment to building a positive future for New York City, while also preserving the memory of the past. By balancing commemoration and commercial development, the new World Trade Center district can serve as a powerful symbol of resilience, hope, and renewal, demonstrating that the city and the nation will never forget the tragedy of September 11, 2001.
